Project Description: To support the outreach concerts and workshops performed by finalists of the quadrennial Classical Fellowship Awards. Each finalist will take part in residency activities including demonstrations, workshops, and master classes in local high schools as part of the Concerto Curriculum program, which will culminate in a public performance by each pianist and members of the Indianapolis Chamber Orchestra. In addition, each finalist will perform a free concert for patients, staff, and the general public at an area hospital.

To support the Concerto Curriculum arts education and community outreach program. The five finalists for the 2014-15 Jazz Fellowship Awards will be able to spend one week during the jazz piano competition in Indianapolis to conduct three-day residencies in local area high schools. They will teach classes, conduct rehearsals, and perform in culminating public concerts with the respective school's jazz ensemble.

To support outreach concerts and workshops performed by the finalists of the quadrennial Classical Fellowship Awards. Each of the five finalists will take part in a three-day residency in local high schools as part of the "Concerto Curriculum" program which will culminate in a public performance by the pianist and members of the Indianapolis Chamber Orchestra in an effort to reinforce the schools' orchestra programs.

To support outreach concerts, workshops, and solo recitals performed by the finalists of the triennial Jazz Fellowship Awards. Each honoree will take part in at least two community events as part of the "Concerto Curriculum" program.

Purpose: To support a mural project featuring lead artist Aaron Johnson-Ortiz. Additional Project Description: Arte Mexicano En Indiana will partner with the Midwest arts group (Neo)Muralismos de México (NMM) to create a mural in the Little Mexico neighborhood of Indianapolis. Aaron Johnson-Ortiz, NMM Director, will work with local youth and community participants to design, create, and install this mural. NMM also will host Mexican artist Gabriel Pozo. Pozo will teach about contemporary mural techniques and share his style of art. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit residents and visitors of Indianapolis. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support Urban Artisans, a vocational internship program for youth with disabilities. Additional Project Description: Under the guidance of professional teaching artists, interns will receive instruction in studio arts and crafts with the primary goal of helping youth participants transition from school to the workforce. Working as a creative team, interns will create artistic products in clay, fiber, paint, and mosaics. Intended Beneficiaries: The internship program will benefit youth participants. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support Urban Artisans, a vocational internship program for youth with disabilities. Under the guidance of professional teaching artists, interns will receive instruction in studio arts and crafts with the primary goal of helping youth participants transition from school to the workforce. Working as a creative team, interns will create artistic products in clay, fiber, paint, and mosaics. Activities will take place virtually and in person.

To support Urban Artisans, a vocational internship program for youth with disabilities. Under the guidance of professional teaching artists, interns receive instruction in studio art and fine art crafts with the primary goal of helping youth participants transition from school to the workforce. Working as a creative team, interns create marketable, artistic products in clay, fiber, paints, and mosaics. Project activities may take place in-person or virtually as necessary.

To support Urban Artisans, a vocational internship program for youth with disabilities. Under the guidance of professional teaching artists, interns receive instruction in studio art and fine art crafts with the primary goal of helping youth participants transition from school to the workforce. Working as a creative team, interns create marketable, artistic products in clay, fiber, paints, and mosaics. Products include functional clay objects such as vases, flower pots, and ceramic bowls and textiles such as scarves. During their time in the program, interns fulfill a commission for a local community partner that sells or distributes the products. Urban Artisans serves central Indiana youth with diagnosed cognitive, emotional, and/or physical disabilities.

Category: National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Awards
Project Description: In recognition of Urban Artisans, an internship program that teaches high school students with disabilities transferable, vocational skills through making, marketing, and selling artwork.

To support community arts classes targeted for children and adults with disabilities as well as at-risk populations. Instructors trained in adaptive arts techniques and methodology in the visual arts, clay, music, and theater will teach participants in an inclusive arts learning environment.

To support a multidisciplinary art program for students with disabilities. Based on the aesthetic inquiry process developed by the Lincoln Center Institute for Aesthetic Education (LCI), the project will launch a cooperative arts education program with Indianapolis Public Schools and includes professional development opportunities for teachers at Lincoln Center.

To support VSAI University Practicum, a new teacher-training program in Indiana. Through collaborations with several Indiana universities, VSAI will provide opportunities for university students in Arts Education methods classes to intern with VSAI Master Artists in VSAI residency programs, where the students will be able to work with children with disabilities.

To support a planning process intended to strengthen the arts council's engagement with communities of color. The council will use research methods including virtual and in person community conversations to identify programming barriers for communities of color in Indianapolis. The findings will inform the development of short- and long-term strategies for increased and inclusive engagement with historically underserved communities.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support IndyArts Education, a collective impact initiative connecting schools with arts organizations to ensure equitable access to arts education for students in Indianapolis. Students in kindergarten through eighth grade will receive dance and theater instruction from long-term partnerships with arts organizations; fine arts teachers will receive professional development in arts integration; and schools will participate in arts-related field trips and Arts Education Week events. Building on an existing mapping tool created through the Kennedy Center's Any Given Child program, IndyArts will track arts access data for each participating school and develop new tools to identify gaps in weekly arts instruction. Data will be made available to the public and thereby help to increase awareness for equity in arts access for students. Project partners include Indianapolis Public Schools, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Kids Dance Outreach, Young Actors Theatre, and Indianapolis University-Purdue University, Indianapolis.

To support training for artists, police, and community members in creative placemaking practices that address public safety challenges. The Indianapolis Neighborhood Resource Center and Marion County Prosecutor's Office will train local artists, police officers, and community members in crime prevention and creative placemaking best practices, engage these trainees in planning arts-based safety interventions, and produce an instructional toolkit based on the program. The Arts Council of Indianapolis will partner with the City of Indianapolis on this project. The project goal is to improve public safety for the estimated 29,000 residents, 40 percent of whom live in poverty, of the IndyEast Promise Zone.

To support the Indianapolis Arts Journalism  Audience Development Project. Partnering with Indiana State University, Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis, and the "Indianapolis Star," project activity will include the creation of a quarterly arts insert in the "Star" and an accompanying printed public art and gallery guide. In addition, the arts council will develop a mobile app that digitizes all quarterly print information for online access along with calendar and event information, venue information, bus and bike routes, walking tours, previews of performances and exhibitions, a public art map, and a gallery guide. Arts previews, arts blogs, and other related content will be created in partnership with IUPUI's school of journalism and Indiana State University's department of communication.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support Developing the Next Arts Audiences Summit 2: a National Audience Development Initiative. The project will be a national meeting focused on engaging younger (ages 20-40) patrons in the arts.

To support Public Art Locator. The documentation of Indianapolis public art will consist of new photo-based artwork, a printed book and map, and an online information center; the project is intended to preserve the historic context in which these works were created and provide educational information about their significance.

To support a Community Arts Development project in partnership with other community organizations. The project is a cultural tourist-oriented public relations and promotional effort related to activities taking place in cultural districts throughout Indianapolis. Partnering organizations will include ndianapolis Downtown, Indianapolis Convention and Visitors Association, and the City of Indianapolis' Office of the Mayor.

To support the creation of a community cultural plan. The Arts Council will develop a strategic cultural tourism plan that addresses how the arts might enhance economic development in the Indianapolis region.

To support the creation of a community cultural plan. Participants in this planning process will develop a collaborative plan to build the arts market and develop new audiences for the arts in Indianapolis.

To support the creation of new work by artists Jason Wesaw and Elisa Harkins and associated community engagement residencies in New Harmony and Indianapolis, Indiana. The project will explore connections between Native American culture and early 19th-century Utopian communities founded in southwestern Indiana. Contemporary artists Jason Wesaw (Potawatomi) and Elisa Harkins (Cherokee/Muscogee) will combine the awareness of the forced displacement and cultural obliteration with aspirational placemaking, both deeply intertwined in Indiana history. Public programming will be designed to contextualize the artwork and facilitate conversations about our shared and challenging histories.

To support artist residencies. Big Car Collaborative resident artists will work with area business people to organize pop-up art activities. This is an effort to spur interest in the commercial corridor; build relationships between business owners, artists, and neighbors; and provide resident artists with unique venues and inspiration for their work. Big Car Collaborative also will host monthly mini-festivals featuring artwork and music during citywide First Friday events.

To support a residency for a teaching sound artist, a citywide sound art project, and related activities. Activities will include participatory listening stations, audio tours of natural locations (such as parks), recordings and digital maps of these locations, and documentation of the project. Sound artists, theorists, and performers will participate.

To support professional development workshops for teachers, master-classes and clinics with professional artists, student matinee performances, post-performance discussions, and related educational activities. The project also will include the preparation of curriculum information and study guides for teachers and students.

To support the creation of a public art project at Still Waters Adult Day Center. A professional artist will work with adults with dementia to create a mixed media work for installation at the center.

Popular Name: aka International Violin Competitiion of Indianap
Project Description: To support educational programs, mentoring, and career development for finalists of the International Violin Competition of Indianapolis. Intensive educational outreach during the competition will include workshops, seminars, and interactive audience talkbacks followed by year round education programs for school students. Competition finalists will take part in various mentoring and career management activities.

Popular Name: aka International Violin Competitiion of Indianap
Project Description: To support a Community Arts Development project in partnership with other community organizations. The project is a cultural tourism effort to promote the "Sixth Quadrennial International Violin Competition," a 17-day festival featuring concerts, recitals, and educational programs. Partnering organizations will include the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, Butler University, Indianapolis Convention and Visitors Bureau, Arts Council of Indianapolis, and the Indiana Historical Society.

To support an artist residency by the Rose Ensemble in consortium with the Society of Biblical Literature. In partnership with the Society of Biblical Literature (SBL), a free public performance, workshops, and demonstrations will take place over five days and will focus on the important role of music in preserving vocal traditions of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

Organization Name: City of Indianapolis, Indiana Department of Public Works
Project Description: To support temporary art and design activities to demonstrate concepts for the permanent redesign of Monument Circle in the heart of downtown Indianapolis. Project activities include an open call for ideas from local artists to propose surprising and experimental arts experiences that illuminate the potential for Monument Circle to become an active hub of the city's cultural and civic life. City of Indianapolis Office of Sustainability, Big Car Collaborative, and Mosaic City will engage residents and visitors to improve the design of this key civic space and its connection to local neighborhoods and other nearby institutions. Spanning four acres, Monument Circle is the epicenter of Indianapolis.

Organization Name: City of Indianapolis, Indiana Department of Public Works
Project Description: To support a consortium project of free public concerts by the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra to diverse audiences in public parks in Indianapolis. Plans for the project include expanding the two free concerts that normally take place each year to four free concerts in new locations.
To support activities that contribute to your creative development and artistic growth and may include writing, research, and travel

To support the presentation of "Remembrances," a ballet in memory of victims of the Holocaust. Remembrances was originally created in 2001 by choreographer David Honigbaum, a former Dance Kaleidoscope dancer. Honigbaum was inspired to create the work after hearing the story of Indianapolis resident Michael Vogel, who survived Auschwitz. The ballet portrays the events of the Holocaust through one family. It blends elements of ballet and modern dance, contains taped interviews of Holocaust survivors, movement imagery, and is set to music that is a mix of classical and contemporary. The work will be performed during Dance Kaleidoscope's fall opening concert at Butler University's Clowes Memorial Hall and will include extensive outreach to central Indiana middle and high school students.

To support a choreographic residency that will result in the creation of a new work for Dance Kaleidoscope. An Indiana native, choreographer Brock Clawson will create a new piece that will premiere at the Indiana Repertory Theatre. Clawson's new piece will reflect on his experience growing up as a young man dancing in a small farm town, and then transitioning to life as a successful dancer in a big city. In addition to creating a new work, Clawson will participate in interactive lecture-discussions designed for students and the general public.
To support the creation and presentation of a new work, choreographed by artistic director David Hochoy. The work will be set to Igor Stravinsky's LES NOCES.
To support the "Modern American Graffiti" dance tour in locations in Indiana. Performances and educational outreach will be held in Muncie,Indiana at Emens Auditorium.

To support a multicultural, in-school educational program in rural areas in Indiana. The Community Investment Residency for the Arts will include a one-week residency by Dance Kaleidoscope and the development of new support materials.
To support activities that contribute to your creative development and artistic growth and may include writing, research, and travel

Organization Name: Eiteljorg Museum of American Indian and Western Art, Inc.
Project Description: Purpose: To support a series of programming celebrating Native American art and culture. Additional Project Description: In conjunction with the opening of the museum's redesigned Native American art gallery, the museum will host performances of Native American dance and drum groups, storytelling, demonstrations, and discussions, as well as guided tours of the new gallery. Additional plans include an artist residency by Karen Ann Hoffman (Haudenosaunee), an educator and storyteller who specializes in Iroquois raised beadwork. All events are planned with virtual/livestream option. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit general audiences in Indianapolis, including the Native American community. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Organization Name: Eiteljorg Museum of American Indian and Western Art, Inc.
Project Description: To support salary costs for the reinstallation of the museum's Native American art galleries. A skilled mount maker will fabricate custom object mounts and develop creative solutions for the long-term installation of more than 350 historic and contemporary Native works at the museum, including textiles, pottery, basketry, sculpture, beadwork, jewelry, and carvings. Museum staff will ensure the highest level of protection, preservation, and aesthetic presentation of these treasures.

Organization Name: Eiteljorg Museum of American Indian and Western Art, Inc.
Project Description: To support presentations and workshops of Native American dance, music, and storytelling in conjunction with the Indian Market and Festival. Performers will include various Native American musicians and dancers presenting traditional and contemporary performance arts, as well as five-time world hoop dance champion Tony Duncan.

Organization Name: Eiteljorg Museum of American Indian and Western Art, Inc.
Project Description: To support the Eiteljorg Indian Market and Festival. Over 100 Native American artists representing dozens of tribes will gather in downtown Indianapolis to present their art, music, dance, craft demonstrations, storytelling, and food. Visitors will have the opportunity to interact with Native American artists and experience the arc of Native art from the traditional to the contemporary.

Organization Name: Eiteljorg Museum of American Indian and Western Art, Inc.
Project Description: To support a symposium on contemporary Native American art. The symposium is part of the sixth biennial Eiteljorg Fellowship for Native American Fine Art program.

Organization Name: Eiteljorg Museum of American Indian and Western Art, Inc.
Project Description: To support SHARE (See and Hear Artists in Residence at the Eiteljorg) with accompanying education programs. SHARE will feature monthly weeklong residencies by Native American and Western visual and performing artists throughout 2008.

Organization Name: Eiteljorg Museum of American Indian and Western Art, Inc.
Project Description: To support a scholarly symposium on the challenges facing Native American contemporary artists in their creative development. The symposium will focus on societal, personal, and cultural issues that surface in the work of Native American artists.

To support Music Unites concerts by Classical Music Indy. Project plans will include Random Acts of Music, unannounced mini-performances in urban areas; after-school concerts and talkback sessions; community concerts in senior centers and neighborhood associations; and listening stations of classical music for community centers, shelters, and libraries.

Purpose: To support an outdoor hip-hop music and dance festival along the White River and Central Canal in Indianapolis. Additional Project Description: The festival activities will focus on themes of water and environmental justice. The event will be curated by Wildstyle Paschall, a local music producer and hip-hop artist. Participating artists will include musicians, visual artists, spoken word artists, and dancers. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will focus on serving diverse and low-income residents of the Near Northwest area of Indianapolis and surrounding neighborhoods. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support design studio internships that promote equity and elevate local voices. Additional Project Description: The program will engage as many as five interns to lead design projects that represent neighborhood priorities and tell community stories in the Martindale Brightwood neighborhood, a Black and historically underserved community in Indianapolis. These design-focused internship positions are part of a larger cultural entrepreneurship initiative established by the Harrison Center for the Arts. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit participating interns as well as residents of the Martindale Brightwood neighborhood. Intended Outcome: Communities are strengthened through systemwide initiatives integrated with the arts.

Purpose: To support an artist residency program. Additional Project Description: A short-term residency designed for traveling musicians will include one day of curated exploration of Indianapolis and one day to celebrate Indianapolis by writing, performing, and recording a song based on the artist's experience. A longer residency also will be offered to musicians or visual artists who want to further develop place-based work and related community building. Housing, studio space, a stipend, and the opportunity for community engagement will be provided for all residencies. Intended Beneficiaries: The residency programs will benefit artists working in music and visual arts. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support residencies for artists working in music and visual arts. A 48-hour residency designed for traveling musicians will include one day of curated exploration of Indianapolis and one day to celebrate Indianapolis by writing, performing, and recording a song based on the artist's experience. A ten-week residency also will be offered to musicians or visual artists who want to further their artwork and related community building. Housing, studio space, a stipend, and the opportunity for community engagement will be provided for all residencies.

To support the creation of a public art sculpture by Quincy Owens and Luke Crawley. The interactive sculpture will be located in the Monon 16 neighborhood, named a federal Promise Zone in 2015. The artwork will contain the voices of neighborhood residents and be inspired by their stories. The sculpture will combine light towers, wood, and found objects, with sound components. The piece will be unveiled as part of a larger civic creative placemaking initiative.

To support artist residencies focused on cultural entrepreneurship and related activities. Resident artists, selected through a competitive application process, will be provided with studio space and living accommodations. The artists will produce or develop personal place-based projects that focus on the local neighborhoods and their history, future, assets, people and/or events.

To support Pre-Enact Indy. The initiative is designed to revive a sense of community pride and fuel both neighborhood and commercial revitalization. Local actors and designers will collaborate with nearby schools and local stakeholders to re-envision the Monon16 neighborhood as a vibrant community via set design and performing arts. Pilot performances will take place in vacant storefronts and abandoned lots to demonstrate the potential of the Monon16 and celebrate existing assets. Partners include Harrison Center for the Arts, City of Indianapolis, and Local Initiatives Support Corporation. Located in a U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development Promise Zone, Monon16 is a neighborhood in which 32.7% of the residents live in poverty and 33% of the 4,098 properties sit vacant.

Purpose: To support staff salaries for the Heartland International Film Festival and Indy Shorts International Film Festival. Additional Project Description: Devoted to inspiring audiences and artists through film, both festivals will include works by U.S. and international artists. Festival screenings will be accompanied by panel discussions and question-and-answer sessions with guest artists or program staff, and educational programming. Intended Beneficiaries: The festivals will serve Indianapolis-area audiences, including residents and visitors, as well as participating artists and venues. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support staff costs for the Heartland International Film Festival and Indy Shorts International Film Festival. Additional Project Description: Devoted to inspiring audiences and artists through film, both festivals will include works by American and international artists. Festival screenings will be accompanied by panel discussions and question-and-answer sessions with guest artists or program staff, and educational programming. Intended Beneficiaries: The festivals will serve Indianapolis-area audiences, including residents and visitors, as well as participating artists and venues. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel and marketing expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support staff salaries for the Heartland International Film Festival and Indy Shorts International Film Festival. Devoted to inspiring audiences and artists through film, both festivals will include films by American and international artists. Festival screenings will be accompanied by panel discussions and question-and-answer sessions with guest artists or staff, and educational programming.

To support staff salaries for the Heartland International Film Festival and Indy Shorts International Film Festival. Devoted to inspiring audiences and artists through film, both festivals will include films by American and international artists. Festival screenings will be accompanied by panel discussions and question-and-answer sessions with guest artists or staff, and educational programming. Some project activities may take place virtually.

To support staffing costs for the 27th Heartland Film Festival. Devoted to inspiring artists and audiences through film, the festival includes narrative features, documentaries, and shorts by American and international artists. Throughout the festival, screenings will be accompanied by panel discussions and question-and-answer sessions with guest artists or staff.

To support the Heartland Film Festival. Devoted to inspiring artists and audiences through film, the festival includes narrative features, documentaries, and shorts by American and international artists. Throughout the festival, screenings will be accompanied by panel discussions and question-and-answer sessions with guest artists or staff.

To support staff salaries as part of the Heartland Film Festival. Films will include narrative features, documentaries, and shorts from American and international artists. Each screening will be accompanied by a question-and-answer session with filmmakers or staff. In addition, the festival will host informal filmmakers' gatherings, workshops, and panel discussions.

To support the 24th Heartland Film Festival and related activities. Films will include narrative features, documentaries, and short films that meet the organization's mission to "inspire filmmakers and audiences through the transformative power of film." In addition, the festival will host informal filmmakers' gatherings, panel discussions, and educational activities.

Purpose: To support arts programs, services, and activities associated with carrying out the agency’s National Endowment for the Arts-approved strategic plan. Additional Project Description: Funding will support state plan priorities, arts education initiatives, underserved communities, the Poetry Out Loud program, and folk and traditional arts programs. The project includes subgranting activity. Intended Beneficiaries: Residents of the agency’s state, including youth, artists, arts organizations, and the general public will benefit from the award. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries experience the exchange of artists, artworks, and arts activities.
To support arts programs, services, and activities associated with carrying out the agency’s National Endowment for the Arts-approved strategic plan.

To support arts programs, services, and activities associated with carrying out the agency’s National Endowment for the Arts-approved strategic plan, as well as administration costs and related subgranting to the nonprofit arts sector in order to preserve jobs and maintain operations to fuel the recovery of the nation’s arts sector from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support arts programs, services, and activities associated with carrying out the agency’s National Endowment for the Arts-approved strategic plan, as well as salaries, administration costs, and related subgranting to the nonprofit arts sector in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
To support arts programs, services, and activities associated with carrying out your agency’s NEA-approved strategic plan.
To support Partnership Agreement activities associated with carrying out your NEA-approved State strategic plan
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support Partnership Agreement activities.
To support Partnership Agreement activities.
To support Partnership Agreement activities,
To support Partnership Agreement activities,
To support Partnership Agreement activities.
To support Partnership Agreement activities,
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support arts projects and activities which preserve jobs in the nonprofit arts sector threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn

To support the 2009 National Accessibility Leadership Award. The Indiana Arts Commission was chosen to receive the 2009 award in recognition of its exceptional and effective initiatives to make the arts fully available to individuals with various disabilities through ArtsWORK Indiana. This six-year-old grassroots partnership is jointly supported by IAC, VSA arts of Indiana, and the Indiana Institute on Disability and Community at Indiana University.
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support Partnership Agreement activities.
To support state participation in "Poetry Out Loud: National Recitation Contest and state-level finals."
To support Partnership Agreement activities.
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support Partnership Agreement activities

To support a Master Artist/Apprenticeship Program and other related costs. The apprenticeship program is designed to identify, document, present, and promote the traditional arts and artists of Indiana.
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support Partnership Agreement activities.

To support the Traditional Arts Indiana (TAI) initiative. Responsibilities will include: 1) programming at the Indiana State Fair; 2) development of a craft marketing program; and 3) a state arts apprenticeship program.
To support Partnership Agreement activities.
To support Traditional Arts Indiana, a statewide folk arts program. This program is dedicated to the support, promotion and presentation of the traditional arts and artists of Indiana.
To support Partnership Agreement activities

To support the establishment of a sustainable system to identify, document, preserve, and promote folk and traditional arts and living folk artists in Indiana. This project is a collaboration between the Indiana Arts Commission and the Indiana University Folklore Institute.
To support Partnership Agreement activities.
To support research and establishment of a traditional arts program to identify, document, preserve, and promote folk and traditional arts and living folk artists in Indiana.

Purpose: To support the touring productions of "Memphis the Musical," with book by Joe DiPietro, music by David Bryan, and lyrics by David Bryan and Joe DiPietro; and "The Wiz," with book by William F. Brown and music and lyrics by Charlie Smalls. Additional Project Description: The organization will partner with local presenters to produce the musicals in Illinois and Indiana. At each location, emerging artists from the local community will have the opportunity to rehearse with and perform alongside the organization's professional cast. Community engagement activities will include field trip experiences for students that feature workshops and post-show discussions with the artists in addition to performance attendance. Intended Beneficiaries: The productions will benefit youth, musical theater artists, and audiences in Chicago and in Fort Wayne and South Bend, Indiana. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Purpose: To support the Inclusion Series, a series of theater productions and community engagement activities that encourage civic dialogue. Additional Project Description: The productions in the series will highlight the experiences of immigrants to the United States. Curated post-show discussions and interactive online resources featuring partners from local organizations will move conversations beyond the theater and into the community. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will benefit theater artists and audiences in Indianapolis. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the INclusion Series, a series of theater productions that encourage civic dialogue. The plays in the series will include Jessica Huang's The Paper Dreams of Harry Chin, which recounts the impact of the Chinese Exclusion Act on an immigrant to the United States; and Cheryl L. West's The Watsons Go to Birmingham, which takes place during the 1963 bombing of the Sixteenth Avenue Church in Birmingham, Alabama. Curated post-show discussions featuring partners from local organizations will move conversations beyond the theater and into the community.

To support the development and planning for Finding Home: Indianapolis at 200, a new devised theater piece with music. The play will build on the success of its predecessor Finding Home: Indiana at 200, which premiered at the theater in honor of Indiana's bicentennial year. The piece will feature a group of Indiana writers who will contribute scenes, monologues, and poems written to explore 200 years of Indianapolis history, woven together with music. Featuring a company of actors and musicians, the collage piece will give voice to unheard viewpoints on the city's past, placing untold stories alongside well-known slices of history.

To support the Exploring Stages education program serving young children. The program utilizes theater texts that teach lessons in language recognition for early readers, empathy building, tolerance, and the understanding of emotional expression. Theater pieces will be produced in an intimate cabaret theater to create an informal, safe, child-scaled space, and to invite the children into the art-making itself. Pre- and post-show activities specifically tailored to the emotional and cognitive development of young children, an in-classroom program, and interactive study guides will complement the production.

To support the final development and production of "Finding Home: Indiana at 200" A devised theater work will celebrate the bicentennial of the founding of the state of Indiana. The play will weave together the songs of balladeer Tim Grimm with Indiana historic events. Playwright-in-residence James Still will curate and collaborate with Indiana artists to create a communal meditation about place and a sense of belonging. The project seeks to expose historic trends of prejudice and to embolden audiences with alternative narratives of state history. Participating writers will hail from a variety of mediums: poets, journalists, playwrights, and novelists who are widely inclusive in age, gender, race, and religion.

To support a production of Kurt Vonnegut's "Who Am I This Time? (and other Conundrums of Love)" by playwright Aaron Posner, with accompanying outreach activities. Based on three stories from Vonnegut's book of short stories "Welcome to the Monkey House," the production will create a public celebration of Vonnegut's work in his hometown. The creative team will include Artistic Director Janet Allen, set designer Russell Metheny, costume designer Rachel Healey, and lighting designer Michael Lincoln.

To support a production of "The Miracle Worker" by William Gibson and related outreach activities, in consortium with VSA Indiana and its statewide affiliates. The project will feature a tour of outreach activities for children with and without disabilities, as well as immersion training for the actors portraying lead roles at the Indiana School for the Blind and Deaf; an approach that will offer new value to participants and that can be emulated by other theaters.

To support the world premiere of playwright James Still's "April 4, 1968." The play is based on an oral history collection from individuals who were present at Robert F. Kennedy's speech announcing the death of Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr.

To support training for teaching artists and an expanded "Summer Conservatory for Youth" program in consortium with Teach for America/Indianapolis. The theater's teaching artists will partner with teachers from Teach For America Indianapolis to develop cross-training practices and art-infused teaching methods as they conduct a summer conservatory and artist-in-the-classroom programs.

To support the commission and development of "April, 4 1968" by playwright-in-residence James Still. The play will be based on Senator Robert Kennedy's six-minute speech in Indianapolis on the night of Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination.
To support a production of "The Diary of Anne Frank," adapted by Wendy Kesselman, and related community outreach activities in consortium with Congregation Beth-El Zedeck.

To support the development and world premiere production of "The Gospel According to James." The project is based on a key moment in Indiana race history and will use historical research, local interviews, and group discussions to inform the creation of the play.

To support a production of "The Heavens Are Hung in Black" by playwright-in-residence James Still and accompanying outreach activities, in consortium with the Indiana Historical Society. The theater will offer community outreach programming in conjunction with the production including student programs and community discussions.

To support the production of plays in repertory by playwright-in-residence James Still, with accompanying community outreach activities. Artistic director Janet Allen will direct "Looking Over the President's Shoulder;" Timothy Douglas is proposed to direct "Iron Kisses."

To support the pre-production and production of "To Kill A Mockingbird" by Harper Lee and adapted by Christopher Sergel with accompanying outreach activities in consortium with Christ Church Cathedral. The partnership will extend the impact of the play outside of the theater and into various community gathering places.

To support a consortium project in partnership with the Conner Prairie Museum for the development, production, and community outreach activities associated with the play "Interpreting William" by James Still. The world premiere play will explore the life of mythic 19th century frontiersman William Conner.
To support a consortium project with Syracuse Stage for productions of "Intimate Apparel" at each theater. The play, written by Lynn Nottage, will be directed by Timothy Douglas.
To support the production of "The Gentleman from Indiana." Based on the 1899 novel by Booth Tarkington, the play will be adapted by playwright James Still and directed by Peter Amster.
To support the commission, workshop, and adaptation of a play based on Booth Tarkington's novel THE GENTLEMAN FROM INDIANA by playwright-in-residence James Still, including an educational component.

To support a project to develop a Greek heroic story into an interdisciplinary theater piece in consortium with Dance Kaleidoscope. Artists from the IRT will collaborate with Dance Kaleidoscope, a professional modern dance ensemble.

To support the expansion of a nationwide distance learning project. Since 1996, the theater has developed and implemented, via video teleconferencing for teachers in rural areas, a program that demonstrates how to integrate theater skills and practices into other core curricular areas of study.

To support a consortium project for the commissioning, research, development, and initial workshops of a new play by James Still. In partnership with Conner Prairie, a living history museum, the theater will commission playwright James Still to explore the significant cross-cultural life of 19th century Indiana frontiersman and fur trader William Conner and his first wife Mekinges, a Lanape Indian.

To support a production of "He Held Me Grand," a major new work by playwright-in-residence James Still. The epic, multidisciplinary, multimedia piece looks at the 20th century through the eyes and remembrances of those who lived it, and is based on stories from senior citizens from the Indianapolis and Philadelphia areas.

To support a bilingual playwrighting class for students in grades 3 to 12, a consortium project. In partnership with the Metropolitan School District of Wayne Township, the project will provide professional development opportunities for approximately 20 teachers and 10 professional artists to observe a course led by playwright James Still.

To support the 2001 Bonderman National Youth Theatre Playwriting Symposium, a consortium project. Indiana Repertory Theatre and the Bonderman Playwriting Symposium (an independent component of Indiana University/Purdue University, Indianapolis/IUPUI) will collaborate on the project.
To support the multi-disciplinary theater classes and workshops program. The education-based program will be offered to adults and youth.

To support the development of a co-commissioned play in consortium with the People's Light  Theatre Company of Malvern, PA. The play, by James Still, will explore the 20th century through the eyes of three generations.

To support the creation of comprehensive, multidisciplinary theater classes and workshop programs serving central Indiana's youth and adults. The classes will augment and heighten audience appreciation of theater.

To support a consortium project for the commissioning, development, and workshop of a stage adaptation of Indiana native Theodore Dreiser's novel "Sister Carrie," by playwright and educator Charles Smith. This consortium project between Indiana Repertory Theatre and Ohio University Theatre Department, Athens, OH will extend the new work development process into a new model of professional and education collaboration.

To support costs for the Discovery Series, a production and educational outreach program for middle and high school students. The Discovery Series consists of three productions and ancillary education services.

To support a community cultural assessment. Indiana Repertory Theatre, Inc. (IRT) will conduct feasibility studies of, and in partnership with, Evansville and Ft. Wayne, Indiana to assess the possibility of extending IRT programming into these two communities.

To support the Discovery Series, an educational program with direct relationship to middle and high school curricula, which includes three fully-produced plays, detailed classroom materials, actor visits in schools, and workshops for teachers. Indiana Repertory Theatre (IRT) seeks support fo rthe components of its 1998-99 Discovery Series season, a three-play education outreach program. The plays are chosen because of their direct link to middle and high school classroom teachings and are supported with detailed ancillary curriculum services for teachers and students which include: preferformance teacher workshops, artist pre-performance classroom visits, comprehensive study guides, post-performance question and answer sessions with artists, suggested reading lists, and play-specific audio and video support materials. Annually, more than 800 schools are served through over 160 performances at the theater. In addition to reaching 60,000 students by the year 2000, IRT is dedicated to increasing artists' salaries and further diversifying casting and outreach initiatives.

Popular Name: aka Indiana State Museum and Historic Sites
Project Description: To support the exhibition It's About Time: The Artwork of Felrath Hines. A 20th-century African-American artist, designer, art conservator, and Indianapolis native, Hines (1913-93) had an eclectic career. He began with a scholarship at the John Herron School of Art. After high school, Hines worked for the Civilian Conservation Corps and began his formal art training at the Art Institute of Chicago. After Chicago, Hines moved to New York City, where he worked as a fashion designer while continuing to paint. A founding member of the Spiral Group in New York City, a group of artists which included Romare Bearden and Norman Lewis, Hines was actively involved with civil rights and close to many top writers, musicians, and artists of the day. The exhibition will include approximately 30 works on loan from his family, cultural institutions, and private collections. The exhibition also will explore his parallel career in art conservation at the National Portrait Gallery and Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, D.C.

Popular Name: aka Indiana State Museum and Historic Sites
Project Description: To support the exhibition "200 Years of Indiana Art: A Cultural Legacy." Organized to coincide with Indiana's Bicentennial celebration in 2016, the exhibition will include a balance of historical and contemporary pieces, providing the visitor with an overview of Indiana history through the visual arts. Early historical works will be featured alongside works by contemporary artists. In an effort to reflect Indiana's changing population and ethnic diversity throughout its history, a team of curators will reach out to working artists, collectors, and cultural institutions for advice and loans.

Purpose: To support Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra's concerts and educational activities focused on composers and musicians from underrepresented communities. Additional Project Description: In partnership with the Sphinx Organization, plans include a chamber concerts series and community performances that seek to focus on serving Black, Latinx, and immigrant communities. Educational activities may include panel discussions and pre-concert programs by Sphinx and by musicians from the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit audiences from the Indianapolis area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support Unheard Voices, a series of concerts and commissions by the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. Additional Project Description: Programming will focus on a particular country or region to highlight the work of lesser known pieces and composers. Commissions for new work will include a piano concerto by composer Jessie Montgomery and a work for narrator and orchestra by composer Joel Thompson. Other composers to be featured will include Joseph de Bologne, Chevalier de Saint-Georges, Florence Price, William Grant Still, Sophie Gubaidulina, and Jerod Tate. Intended Beneficiaries: The performances will be promoted to audiences throughout the Indianapolis area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the Teddy Bear Series, an early childhood education program by the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. Designed for young children, the series is based on stories written by ISO violinist Victoria Kitner Griswold. The performances will be free to the public and held in accessible locations including public libraries and preschools throughout central Indiana.

To support a concert series celebrating Beethoven's 250th birthday performed by the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. Repertoire will include his symphonies and concertos, as well as new works by composers such as Nathaniel Stookey, Hannah Lash, Dejan Lazic, Huw Watkins, and Katherine Balch. Educational activities may include pre-concert talks.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the Metropolitan Youth Orchestra, an instrumental music instruction program. Metropolitan Youth Orchestra (MYO) is designed to serve K-12 students in the most impoverished neighborhoods in Marion County, Indiana. Participants will receive music education, mentoring, and opportunities for family engagement. A group of parents and guardians will learn to play an instrument alongside their children in an MYO orchestra, providing them with shared skills and experiences. Program goals include improving high school graduation rates in the communities served and transitioning students to a four-year university or vocational certificate program. A student leadership team, selected through a competitive application process, will contribute to the management of MYO.

To support the Lunch Break Series by the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. The series will comprise midday concerts lasting less than an hour with the goal of introducing new audiences to the symphonic art form. Repertoire will feature a variety of classical works and patriotic favorites in the Hilbert Circle Theatre in downtown Indianapolis.

To support the 317 Series of concerts and educational activities by the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. Named for central Indiana's area code, the series will present full orchestra concerts in outlying, underserved communities along with related educational events and neighborhood activities. Performance opportunities will be developed for orchestra musicians such as performing as guest soloists with school orchestras. Educational activities will include master classes, sectional rehearsals with orchestra musicians, audition workshops, and pre-concert Behind the Music discussion sessions.

To support a residency by the string trio Time for Three with the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. The trio performs music with roots in classical, bluegrass, and jazz. They will serve as creative directors for the symphony's Happy Hour at the Symphony series where they will curate concerts in collaboration with New Amsterdam Presents, an artists' service organization that promotes mixed-genre new music.

To support the commissioning and presentation of a new work by composer William Bolcom, performed by the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, with related educational activities. The work titled "Games and Challenges: Something Wonderful Right Away" will be scored for string trio and orchestra.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the ISO Metropolitan Youth Orchestra. The program includes weekly lessons, rehearsals, adjudications and performance opportunities for underserved students in Indianapolis.

To support the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra's Nueva Vida (New Life) Project with composer Gabriela Lena Frank. Focusing on discussions and interactions with community members who recently immigrated to central Indiana from Central America, composer Gabriela Lena Frank will create a new orchestral work based on these dialogues.
To support the production and distribution of the radio series Indianapolis On-The-Air. Featuring the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, the 13-part series is heard on more than 250 radio stations.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Arts Everyday. Serving six schools in four school districts, the music education program is expected to provide in-school arts instruction for 2,700 elementary students and more than 130 classroom teachers.
To support the production and distribution of the radio series "Indianapolis On-The-Air." Featuring the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, the 13-part series is heard on more than 250 radio stations.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support continuation of the School Partner Program. The professional development project provides Indianapolis public school teachers with the training and skills necessary to teach an arts-integrated curriculum and supplies the resources necessary to implement the program for students in kindergarten to 5th grade.

To support the production and distribution of the radio series "Indianapolis On-The-Air." Featuring the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, the 13-part series is heard on more than 250 radio stations in 41 states.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the continuation of the School Partner Program.

To support the Freedom Initiative, in celebration of the Orchestra's 75th anniversary season. Plans include concerts, a commission, world premieres, a festival of women composers, and numerous educational activities.
To support the continuation of the "School Partner Program." The project uses the arts to teach core curricula to a diverse social and economic representation of Indianapolis children.
To support the presentation of Michael Torke's RAPTURE; including outreach activities.
To support CELEBRATE AMERICA and the SPRING FESTIVAL OF MUSIC BY LIVING COMPOSERS. The Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra will host an American composer and commission a new work.

To support the "Neighborhood Harmony Project," an outreach project with community centers in Indianapolis. During 2000-01, the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra will provide music performances and educational programs for children in low-income families.

To support the "Music of Spain Festival," consisting of performances by the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra of classical symphonic music by Spanish composers and composers influenced by the Spanish culture and style of music composition and educational activities. The three-week festival is currently scheduled to take place in January 2000.
To support the 1999 Spring Festival entitled "Nature in Sight and Sound" comprised of symphonic music performed to photography of nature projected over the stage by American artist James Westwater.

To support a series of community planning activities to inform a new percent for art program. Project activities will include stakeholder meetings to identify priorities and map existing cultural assets. Key partners include Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis Arts  Humanities Institute, the Mayor's Office of Indianapolis, and the Arts Council of Indianapolis. The new percent for art program will ensure that public art funds ultimately are distributed in response to local neighborhood goals and priorities, particularly in areas of concentrated poverty where public art investments have been historically lacking.

To support a series of studies examining higher education investments in physical and programmatic arts infrastructure in the United States. The quasi-experimental studies will consider the link between arts infrastructure investments in colleges and universities and various student-, school-, and community-level outcomes. The project will involve pre- and post-surveys of Indiana University-Bloomington students, to track the potential effects of the school's recent arts infrastructure initiative, and of expanded arts programming. Researchers also will use nationally representative data sources such as McGraw-Hill Construction building permit data (to review trends in physical infrastructure spending at places of higher education), the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (to mine administrative data from schools participating in federal student financial aid programs), and U.S. Census Bureau and Bureau of Labor Statistics datasets (to assess socioeconomic indicators at the community level). Among outcome variables to be measured in relation to schools' arts investments are: students' rates of enrollment, majors, graduation, and participation in arts and cultural activities; charitable donations; and creative sector employment at the community level.

To support a study of artists' employment patterns relative to prior decades and how artists found new markets during and after the recent recession. Researchers will construct a longitudinal study sample from data files produced by the U.S. Census Bureau's Current Population Survey. The study also will yield a new data file consisting of "web scrapes" from the crowdfunding sites Kickstarter and Indiegogo, partly to understand variations in fundraising outcomes of arts projects compared with technology and non-arts projects.

To support the Herron School of Art and Design's Honor's Art Program. The classes will introduce students to core art and design principles by emphasizing a strong foundation in drawing, design, color theory, and technical training.

Purpose: To support a community-based after-school and summer visual arts program. Additional Project Description: Providing year-round opportunities to youth from underserved neighborhoods in Indianapolis, ArtReach will connect students with professional artists who teach weekly classes grounded in the elements of discipline-based arts education (art-making, art history, art criticism, and aesthetics). The program will culminate in an exhibition. Intended Beneficiaries: ArtReach will serve youth participants from underserved neighborhoods through partnerships with Indianapolis Public Schools, domestic violence shelters, residential treatment facilities, transitional housing, and community centers. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support a community-based after-school and summer visual arts program. Additional Project Description: Providing opportunities to youth from underserved neighborhoods in Indianapolis, ArtReach will connect students with professional artists who teach weekly classes grounded in the elements of discipline-based arts education (art-making, art history, art criticism, and aesthetics). The program will culminate in an exhibition. Intended Beneficiaries: ArtReach will serve youth participants from underserved neighborhoods through partnerships with Indianapolis Public Schools, domestic violence shelters, residential treatment facilities, transitional housing, and community centers. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support ArtReach, a community-based after-school and summer visual arts program. Providing year-round opportunities to youth from underserved neighborhoods in Indianapolis, ArtReach will connect students with professional artists who teach weekly classes grounded in the elements of discipline-based arts education (art-making, art history, art criticism, and aesthetics). The program culminates in an annual exhibition that takes place each spring.

To support ArtReach, a community-based after-school and summer visual arts program. Providing year-round opportunities to youth from underserved neighborhoods in Indianapolis, ArtReach will work with participants at multiple sites across the city. ArtReach will connect students with professional artists who teach weekly classes grounded in the elements of discipline-based arts education (art-making, art history, art criticism, and aesthetics). The sequential lesson plans culminate in an annual ArtReach exhibition that takes place each spring.

To support the expansion of the ArtReach visual arts education programming. ArtReach is a community-based, year-round, visual arts program for underserved youth in Indianapolis. Youth participants learn art-making techniques in a variety of media including photography, painting, and watercolor. They also receive instruction in art history, art criticism, and aesthetics.

To support the Summer Exhibition Series: Storytellers. Inspired by the art of storytelling, the Center will present a visual arts exhibition, install a new commissioned public art work, and feature a series of engagement activities including participatory storytelling events, puppetry workshops, and interactive performances based on works in the Center's art park.

To support an artist residency engagement program in central Indiana. During a one-week residency an emerging or mid-career Midwestern artist will create a site-specific installation using recycled materials and conduct a public lecture demonstration; the installation will focus on transparency of process and issues of sustainability.

To support the commissioning of two site-specific projects by artists Susan Wink and Drea Howenstein for the center's proposed "Sensory Path" to be installed along the White River. The Indianapolis Art Center is sited on seven acres and has recently completed an expansion from 10,000 to over 40,000 square feet. Development of a "Sensory Path" is the next phase of the project and will provide visitors with the opportunity to interact with works of art that are integrated into the natural environment. Howenstein proposes to create an environmental reclamation of sorts a contemplative garden for a vacant lot that will help control run-off with appropriate low-maintenance plantings. The second artist, Susan Wink, proposes to build a sculpture into the side of a hill, consisting of three hollow mesh structures shaped like kernels of corn. The structures will house dried ears of corn at the center of which sweet corn will be planted to be harvested at the project's conclusion and offered to a local homeless shelter. Each artist will receive an honorarium, and all materials and construction costs will be covered by the Center. Additionally, educational programming will be developed with the Indianapolis Parks Department.

To support ICO-Go! concerts. Violinist Bella Hristova will engage in a series of outreach concerts, including a free, in-school performance at Emmerich Manual High School and a concert held on the grounds of the Indiana Women's Prison.

To support the Indianapolis Children's Choir Everyone COUNTS (Community Outreach Uniting  Nurturing Through Song) initiative. Project components will include tuition assistance to children enrolled in ICC ensembles, after-school choral music education instruction for elementary and middle school students in regional choirs, and early childhood music classes held at sites throughout the community. Other program components will include the "Jubilate Choir" for children with special needs and the ICC Innovations program, which provides free resources and services to music teachers and schools throughout central Indiana.

To support the Everyone COUNTS program. Choral conductors will provide in-school and after-school music instruction to students in underserved communities. The project will include on-site workshops for classroom teachers at local schools as well as tuition assistance to children enrolled in Preparatory Programs, Children's Performance Choirs, and High School Performance Choirs. Other program components will include early childhood music classes to sites throughout the community, support for regional choirs at satellite locations, and the "Jubilate Choir" for children with special needs.
To support the "ENCORE" performance of signature pieces from a modern dance repertoire. The company will present pieces chosen by audiences, dancers, and staff.

To support the creation of new backdrops and sets for the Gregory Hancock Dance Theatre's production of "Dracula." The new scenic design, which replaces the smaller original, will suit the more prestigious, larger venues where the GHDT performs this popular staple of its repertoire.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel and marketing expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel and safety supplies expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support public programming associated with a series of exhibitions of Japanese prints, fashion, Noh masks, and Samurai armor. The museum plans extensive public programming throughout the 152-acre campus including a month-long residency with performance artist Mitsu Salmon, who will address themes of translation, migration, and diaspora. The residency will include open rehearsals, workshops, and performances in spaces throughout the museum grounds. Additional public programming will include curator talks, docent-led tours, horticulture classes, art-making activities, music performances, educational tours, and a film festival.

A Brush with Beauty: Japanese Paintings in Ink, Color, and Gold The exhibition will feature hanging scrolls, hand scrolls, and folding screens largely from the Edo Period, focusing thematically on the relationships between masters and disciples of various schools of painting. Beyond exploring the representative styles of the schools, the exhibition will highlight the great masters of Japanese art, and the stylistic influences and cross-fertilization that are among the schools. Accompanying programming will include curator and artist talks, docent tours, theater and music performances, and horticulture workshops. Exhibition-based curriculum and hands-on activities will be developed for children and adults.

To support programmatic evaluation and research to investigate how best to present contemporary art. The museum's media and technology team will conduct formative prototype testing and summative research, and collect data to inform the development of interpretive content and engagement activities for both exhibitions, as well as for the future reinstallation of its contemporary collection. The research and testing will complement the presentation of two exhibitions.

To support an exhibition series,"CSI: Conservation Science Indianapolis." The exhibition series will familiarize the public with basic conservation science, exploring the imaging and analytical technologies applied to the study and interpretation of art works in the museum's collection. The exhibitions will demonstrate such techniques as the use of radiography and infrared imaging, colorant analysis, and provenance research of clues such as artist inscriptions, or the use of labels, wax seals, or other markings to establish history of ownership or authenticity. Showcased in galleries throughout the museum, each exhibition will include art works and interpretation material such as text, visuals, and videos, to explain the methods used for the analysis, as well as an analog or digital activity that will allow visitors to apply the technique themselves.

To support a technology-based interpretive installation for the exhibition, "Dream Cars: Innovative Design, Visionary Ideas." The installation will encourage multi-sensory interaction with related objects and concepts. Feedback from the project will be used to inform future technology-based visitor engagement plans and will be disseminated to the field at-large.

To support the exhibition and catalogue, "Face to Face: The Neo-Impressionist Portrait, 1886-1904." The exhibition will explore the character, context, and diversity of Neo-Impressionist portraiture through the presentation of approximately 45 paintings and 20 works on paper by 19 artists such as Georges Seurat, Paul Signac, Maximilien Luce, Theo van Rysselberghe, Vincent van Gogh, and Jan Toorop.

To support conservation and installation of the museum's Western European contemporary design collection. The project will enable the museum to display approximately 350 objects from a variety of media, including furniture, glass, ceramics, metalwork, and product design in a reconfigured 9,000 square foot gallery space.

To support FLOW (Can You See the River), a collaborative public art project by artist Mary Miss. With a series of collaborative installations along a stretch of the White River and Central Canal in Indianapolis, artist Mary Miss aims to enhance residents' awareness of the White River, river-related issues, and existing efforts that keep the city's primary water source healthy.

To support public programming related to the exhibition, "Hard Truths: The Art of Thornton Dial". Programs will engage a diverse public audience by addressing the social, political, and philosophical themes in Dial's work.

To support an exhibition of the work of contemporary AfroCuban artist Maria Magdalena Campos-Pons (b.1959), with accompanying catalogue and educational programs. The exhibition will feature paintings, room-size media installations, and large format Polaroid photographs that the artist has produced during the last 20 years.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Thinking Through Art. Working in partnership with the Indiana Department of Education and the Eiteljorg Museum of American Indians and Western Art, the museum will offer training and resources for classroom teachers to implement a statewide arts curriculum including the production of new CDs with images from partnering museums.

To support the exhibition "Gifts to the Tsars, 1550-1700: Treasures from the Kremlin," and accompanying education programs. Objects in the exhibition will be loaned by the Armoury, the principle component of the State Museum Preserve of History and Culture at the Moscow Kremlin.

To support the "Community Connections" program, conducted by a group of African-American high school students, which provides thematic presentations and participatory activities linked to the museum's special exhibitions and collections throughout Indiana, and targets rural and inner-city community organizations. "Community Connections" was developed as part of a 1993 Lila Wallace Reader's Digest grant to the museum to make its collections and programs more accessible to the public and to increase African-American participation. The museum's most important exhibition in 1998 will be "King of the World," organized by the Sackler Museum in Washington, DC, consisting of 44 manuscripts, lent by the Royal Library, Windsor Castle, which chronicle the life of emperor Shah-Jahan (1627-1658), the builder of the Taj Mahal. The beautifully illustrated paintings were created to honor the 50th anniversary of India's independence from England. The students in the program will be engaged in intensive orientation and training sessions related to the exhibition and Indian culture and history, conducted by the museum's curatorial and education staff. During this training, the students will learn about the history of India, and the culture, religion, beliefs, geography. and everyday life of the Indian people.

To support "Music! Words! Opera!" The literature-based, K-12 educational project, will provide teacher manuals and training, audiotapes, study guides, and attendance at performances, open rehearsals, and workshops for teachers and approximately 5,000 students from 10 schools.

To support MUSIC! WORDS! OPERA! (M!W!O!) for elementary, middle, and high school students and teachers in metropolitan Indianapolis schools. M!W!O! is a sequenced and integrated curriculum developed by OPERA America that explores historic, linguistic, and artistic diversity through the study of opera.

Category: Challenge America Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a partnership project of artist-led activities that provides positive alternatives for youth. The partnership with The Rise Extended Living Shelter will provide theater training with a concentration on improvisational acting for children living in this shelter for battered families. Instruction will be offered on a weekly basis during after school hours to youths living in the shelter. In addition to professional theater instructors, counselors will be available to provide support to program participants.

To support the translation from the Polish of a collection of poems by Jacek Dehnel. One of Poland's most highly regarded and prolific young writers, Dehnel (b. 1980) has published eight collections of poetry and 15 works of prose. He is also an acclaimed translator of Anglophone literature, including F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby, Henry James's The Turn of the Screw, and Philip Larkin's Collected Poems, among others. Dehnel's poems are simultaneously traditional in form and contemporary in subject matter, employing the classic 13-syllable line and intricate rhyming stanzas to explore scientific developments, the proliferation of Internet culture, and his life as a gay man in Poland. Tentatively titled Parallel Lives: Poetic Suites, the translated work will draw from two of Dehnel's books: Columns of Gains and Losses and Foreign Languages.
To support the translation of poetry written by Polish writer Agnieszka Kuciak.

To support the 12th Annual United States Latvian Song and Dance Festival. The festival will provide a view into the heritage, customs, and traditions of the Latvian people of Northeastern Europe and of their descendants in North America.
To support the Theatre Series presentation of a production by Root Wy'mn Theatre Company.

To support a consortium project for the research and development stages of "Blues Migration," an oral history project that will explore the migration of African American people and the migration of the blues. This consortium effort is in collaboration with Blues City Cultural Center, Mephis, TN; DuSable Museum, Chicago, IL; Hayti Heritage Center, Durham, NC; CArver Community Cultural Center, San Antonio, TX and King Arts Complex, Columbus, OH.

To support the Directors' Academy component of the Summer Symposium at Ball State University. During the instrumental music professional development program, music teachers improve their classroom rehearsal techniques, conducting, score study, and repertoire selection by working with field experts and students.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Music for All Summer Symposium Teachers' Academy, a week-long national instrumental music and leadership professional development program. Using experiential learning, the academy trains teachers who work directly with student musicians.

Purpose: To support the New Harmony Project's new play development conference. Additional Project Description: During the gathering of writers and artists in New Harmony, Indiana, scripts will be developed, workshopped, and presented to the community. New plays will be created with the participation of nationally recognized directors, dramaturgs, and actors, as well as students from local colleges and universities. Intended Beneficiaries: The conference will serve theater artists and audiences in Southern Indiana, and the nationwide theater field will benefit from the creation of new work. Intended Outcome: Arts leaders develop professional skills and strategies.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support the 34th annual spring conference, which will gather writers and artists virtually for a two-week creative retreat. Scripts are developed, workshopped, and presented to the community with the participation of nationally recognized directors, dramaturgs, and actors, as well as students from local colleges and universities.

To support residencies for playwrights to develop new work with dramaturgical and production support.
