The project serves writers who create new works for stage, television, film, and new media that explore and celebrate the human spirit. Competitively selected playwrights will be paired with directors, dramaturgs, and actors for daily script-in-hand rehearsals that will culminate in final readings of new scripts for a community of participants and supporters. The project also will offer internship opportunities for college theater students, observerships for high school theater students, and free, open play readings to the rural southwest Indiana community.

To support residencies for playwrights to develop new work with dramaturgical and production support. Competitively selected playwrights will be paired with directors, dramaturgs, and actors for daily script-in-hand rehearsals that will culminate in final readings of new scripts for a community of participants and supporters. The project also will offer internship opportunities for college theater students, observerships for high school theater students, and free, open play readings to the rural southwest Indiana community.

To support residencies for playwrights to develop new work with dramaturgical and production support. Competitively selected playwrights will be paired with directors, dramaturgs, and actors for daily script-in-hand rehearsals that will culminate in final readings for a community of participants and supporters. The project also will offer internship opportunities for college theater students, observerships for high school theater students, and free, open readings to the rural southwest Indiana community.

Category: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
Project Description: To support Sewanee Summer Music Festival: Bela Fleck Commission Project.

To support two-week residencies for playwrights to develop new work with dramaturgical and production support. The program culminates in public readings and discussions, and is augmented by educational components involving local high school and college students.

To support the "New Harmony Project," a new play development conference. Participating writers will work with a company of artists for developmental readings of new work, and emerging writers and high school and college participants will receive mentoring by more established

Category: Challenge America: Arts Education in American Communities
Project Description: To support the Artists in Residence Program of the 54th Sewanee Summer Music Festival. Music students age 12 through college will participate in master classes and attend multiple informative live public concerts by professional artists in classical, jazz, and world music.
To support a two-week writers' conference for new play development. Educational programs and opportunities for local residents to participate will also be offered.

To support a new play development writers conference. The annual two-week conference provides writers with an opportunity to develop scripts in a supportive community of professional directors, actors, dramaturges, and support staff.

To support the 2006 "New Harmony Project," which culminates in an annual conference for playwrights. The project will include staged readings of works, a residency program, and internships for college students.

To support the artist faculty fees for the 2006 Sewanee Summer Music Festival. Ensemble musicians of high caliber will be engaged to teach the approximately 200 young artists participating in the five-week instructional program, as well as to perform in the festival's professional concert series. The artists selected to serve as the 2006 faculty are Ryan Anthony, James Box, Bernard Flythe, and Jeff Nelson. Messrs. Anthony and Nelson are members of the Canadian Brass; Mr. Box is the Principal Trombone with the Montreal Philharmonic, and Dr. Flythe is Assistant Professor of Tuba and Euphonium at Austin Peay State University. The educational program will include private lessons, chamber music coaching, master classes, and sectional rehearsals. Music theory, conducting, and composition/arranging classes also will be offered. In addition to exposing the students to the finest orchestral and chamber music literature, the goal is to teach them the basics of being a professional performing musician, from instrument mastery and care to deportment and professional courtesy.

To support a music ensemble for the 2005 Sewanee Summer Music Festival. The ensemble, who will be chosen through a competitive process, will perform publicly as well as teach student instrumentalists selected to attend the festival's education program.

To support an annual playwrights conference in the former utopian community of New Harmony, Indiana. During each conference, competitively selected playwrights work in a supportive community of professional actors, directors, and dramaturgs to create new works for theater, musical theater, and film.
To support a conference for playwrights to develop new scripts through workshops, readings, and rehearsals.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Purpose: To support the annual Percussive Arts Society International Convention. Additional Project Description: The service organization's conference for musicians and music educators (particularly percussionists) will offer concerts, clinics, master classes, labs, workshops, panels, and presentations by artists from around the world. Performers and participants will include students, music educators, professional musicians, music scholars, and hobbyists of all ages. The conference will be held in Indianapolis and also offer options for virtual participation. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve individual attendees from around the country and the world, as well as audiences of all ages during the performances. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support "Heritage," a series of plays by artists of color exploring the history, mythology, and cultural inheritance of people of different races and cultural backgrounds. The series will include "River City" by Diana Grisanti, a play which explores the struggles and legacy of the civil rights movement in Louisville, Kentucky. The series also will feature "Dontrell, Who Kissed the Sea," a play in verse about a young black man's search for connection to his ancestors, as well as a new play with music by Caridad Svich based on a Mexican folk tale. The series is designed to develop and produce work that reflects Indianapolis's increasingly diverse population, to expand audience engagement with culturally diverse work, and to increase performing opportunities for artists of color.

To support the collaborative creation and production of two plays by artists from a variety of theater disciplines under the artistic leadership of playwright Toni Press-Coffman. The goal of the project is to develop the work of artists from different cultural backgrounds, creating pieces that offer unique perspectives on issues surrounding race, culture, and ethnicity.
To support "Fourplay," a series of plays that explore sexual mores at the beginning of a new century. The plays will be presented in repertory over three months at the Phoenix Theatre.
To support general operating costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support a series of educational workshops that will culminate with the fabrication and installation of public art. Students from Knightstown Elementary will attend a series of workshops where they will explore how to transform a vacant space in their community, a rural town east of Indianapolis. A professional teaching artist will lead the student participants through the design process and a presentation to the community. After community feedback is reviewed, the artist will create and install the piece of public art.

To support the design and creation of a public artwork and related educational programming. Arts for Learning will partner with Starke County Youth Club, in rural Starke County, Indiana, to help students design meaningful artwork for an accessible location in the community. The community will provide consultation throughout the design stages, and after the artwork is complete the community will provide feedback via evaluations. The students will learn from practicing artists in their region, and local teaching artists will learn how to involve residents of their community in a public art project to enhance neighborhood identity.

To support Fresh StART, a public art project inspired by students at schools in rural Jennings County, Indiana. Students will design meaningful works of art for their school's campus and another accessible location in their community. Professional teaching artists will lead workshops in Jennings County High School. The initial workshops will explore community problems as raised by the students during the idea-gathering phase of the program; the later workshops will be devoted to conceptualizing the public artworks. The installation of the artworks will be celebrated in a culminating community-wide event.

Category: National Arts and Humanities Youth Program Awards
Project Description: In recognition of the Young Audiences of Indiana (Summer Arts for Youth), for their work in promoting interdisciplinary summer arts programming to underserved youth.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Young-at-Arts, a multidisciplinary arts education program, in consortium with the Day Nursery Association of Indianapolis. In partnership with Day Nursery Association of Indianapolis, the project will provide age-appropriate arts activities for children ages three to six and professional development for their teachers.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support "Young-at-Arts" in consortium with the Day Nursery Association. Professional artists who are trained and experienced in early childhood arts education will lead age-appropriate learning experiences in music, dance, theater, and visual arts

To support the Summer Arts for Youth and Arts Partners programs. Economically disadvantaged youth, ages 6 to 11, in up to eight Indianapolis community sites will participate in multidisciplinary arts and literature activities as part of the curriculum.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support Young-at-Arts, an early-childhood arts education consortium project with the Day Nursery Association of Indianapolis. Age-appropriate learning experiences in music, dance, theater, and visual arts will occur in multiple sessions.

To support the Summer Arts for Youth (SAY) and the Arts Partners (AP) programs. Economically disadvantaged youth, ages 6 to 11, in up to eight Indianapolis community sites will participate in multidisciplinary arts and literature activities as part of the curriculum.

To support the Summer Arts for Youth (SAY) Program. Low-income youth in eight Indianapolis community sites will participate in multidisciplinary arts and literature activities as part of the summer program's curriculum.
To support the Summer Arts for Youth program and the Arts Partners in-school program.

To support professional training for artists and teachers. Based on the Reggio Emilia approach to early learning, artists will design and implement residencies in music, theater, dance, and the visual arts.

Category: Challenge America Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a partnership project of artist-led activities that provides positive alternatives for youth. The partnership with Marion County Juvenile Detention Center will provide a series of arts residencies in music, dance,

Discipline / Field: Creative Links: Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a Creative Links project to provide positive alternatives for youth. The partnership brings together the Martin Luther King Multi-Service Center, Hispanic Education Center, Dayspring Center, Flanner House-Watkins Park Youth Center, Universal United Methodist Church, Concord Multi-Service Center and East 10th United Methodist Children and Youth Center to help fund Summer Arts for Youth. This program allows inner-city, low-income youths, ages 8 to 14, to work with professional artists in music, dance, drama and visual arts.

To support a community cultural assessment and the creation of a community cultural plan for arts education. A consultant will be hired to survey counties in south-central Indiana to determine arts education needs and develop a plan to address those needs.

To support the Cornerstone Dance Project: Positive Interaction through Dance. This is a collaboration between Young Audiences of Indiana and the Metropolitan School District of Washington Township to provide a sequential dance education program based on the voluntary National Standards for Dance Education at the elementary- and middle-school levels.
